li.a: Important Notes for Staff and Faculty

div.p: Tuesday, April 21, 2020 9:23 am

div.class: elementor-element elementor-element-6e1af98 elementor-hidden-desktop elementor-hidden-tablet elementor-widget elementor-widget-image
elementor-element elementor-element-b8c7632 elementor-hidden-desktop elementor-hidden-tablet elementor-widget elementor-widget-image

div.p: A new type of coronavirus, abbreviated COVID-19, is causing an outbreak of respiratory (lung) disease. It was first detected in China and has now been detected internationally. While the immediate health risk in the United States is still considered to be low, the disease is spreading and the situation is being closely monitored. Concern over this new virus can make children and families anxious. While we do not know where and to what extent the disease may spread here in the United States, we do know that it is contagious, that the severity of illness can vary from individual to individual, and that there are steps we can take to prevent the spread of infection. The virus can be especially severe for elderly people. Acknowledging some level of concern, without panicking, is appropriate and can result in taking actions that reduce the risk of illness. Helping children cope with anxiety requires providing accurate prevention information and facts without causing undue alarm. It is very important to remember that children look to adults for guidance on how to react to stressful events. If parents seem overly worried, children’s anxiety may rise. Parents should reassure children that health and school officials are working hard to ensure that people throughout the country stay healthy. However, children also need factual, age appropriate information about the potential seriousness of disease risk and concrete instruction about how to avoid infections and spread of disease. Teaching children positive preventive measures, talking with them about their fears, and giving them a sense of some control over their risk of infection can help reduce anxiety.

div.class: elementor-element elementor-element-78434b3 elementor-icon-list--layout-inline elementor-align-center elementor-widget elementor-widget-icon-list

p.strong: Federal and State Level:

p.a: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

p.strong: New Guidance and Documents from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC):

div.p: Cleaning and disinfecting of schools (non-health care facilities) – https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/cleaning-disinfection.html
CDC Checklist for getting prepared for school administrators, teachers and parents – https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/checklist.html
FAQs for Schools – https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/schools-faq.html

p.strong: Many Posters Available in Multiple Languages:

div.p: There are also a significant number of posters available in many languages that could be printed and posted at school sites and/or sent home to families, available here: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/communication/factsheets.html

p.strong: Educating Parents and Children about COVID-19:

p.a: Talking to Children About H1N1 Flu
NJ Department of Health COVID-19 Guidence for Child Care and K-12 Schools

p.strong: Ways to cope with COVID-19:

p.a: Coping With Stress During Infectious Disease Outbreaks
Taking Care of Your Behavioral Health
10 Ways to Respond to Fear and Scapegoating During the Coronavirus Epidemic
Navigating the Behavioral Health Impacts of the Coronavirus

div.p: General fact sheet on COVID-19, available in multiple languages at https://nyc.gov/coronavirus

p.a: Coronavirus FAQ for NYC schools and families
NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene’s Coronavirus Page

div.p: Document continually updated
Document continually updated​

p.strong: Q: Will I be able to communicate with my child’s teacher(s) during the iContinue Learning School Day?

div.p: A: Yes, your child’s teacher(s) will be available to answer your questions via email, Class Dojo and/or Schoology.

p.strong: Q: Will my child be responsible for completing assignments during iContinue Learning?

div.p: A: Yes, your child will receive daily assignments during the iContinue Learning period. These assignments will count towards a grade and attendance. Please see the iContinue Learning Plan for specific details.

p.strong: Q: What if my child is sick during the iContinue Learning period?

div.p: A: If your child is sick, please communicate with the school nurse, your child’s teacher and/or school administration.

p.strong: Q: What if my child has a question about an assignment?

div.p: A: All teachers will have office hours, where they will be available to answer student questions about an assignment.

p.strong: Q: Will my child have the same daily schedule during iContinue Learning?

div.p: A: Schedules will be adjusted during the iContinue Learning period to facilitate online instruction, teachers will share schedules with students and parents. You can refer to the iContinue Learning Plan for specifics as well.

p.strong: Q: How can I monitor my child’s Academic Progress during iContinue Learning?

div.p: Communication platforms/LMS (Schoology, ClassDojo, Seesaw, Google Classroom, School Database, etc.), assignments and grades posted in the school database, or other practices already used by teachers and parents will remain available.

p.strong: Q: Will my child continue to receive modifications/accommodations?

div.p: A: Yes, your child’s special education teacher will continue to plan along with your child’s general education teacher. Assignments will be graded by the special education teacher.

p.strong: Q: Will I be able to communicate with my child’s special education teacher(s) during the iContinue Learning School Day?

div.p: A: Yes, your child’s special education teacher(s) will be available to answer your questions via email, Class Dojo and/or Schoology.

p.strong: Q: Will I be able to communicate with my child’s case manager?

div.p: A: Yes, you can contact your child’s case manager either through email or by calling their office phone number.

p.strong: Q: Will my child continue to receive counseling services?

div.p: A: During this time, your child will not receive school counseling services; however, social workers and school psychologists will conduct periodic check-ins with students.

p.strong: Q: Will my child continue to receive related services?

div.p: A: During this time, your child will not receive related services. Case managers will keep record of missed services, and determine if services need to be made up once we return to school.

p.strong: Q: What if I have an annual review or other planning meeting scheduled for my child?

div.p: A: Annual reviews and planning meetings can be conducted via digital platforms. Your child’s case manager will send you a digital invitation.

p.strong: Q:Will my child continue to receive ESL lessons?

div.p: A: Your child’s ESL teacher will continue to plan lessons in alignment to the curriculum. K-8 students will have week-long project based learning assignments. 9-12 students will utilize Schoology to complete their assignments.

p.strong: Q: Will my child need to complete the WIDA Access assessment?

div.p: A: The WIDA Access schedule will be adjusted when school reopens. Any updates regarding testing will be shared with families.

p.strong: Q: Will iStellar sessions continue during this time?

div.p: A: All iStellar sessions have been cancelled until schools reopen.

p.strong: Q: Will state/national competitions proceed as scheduled?

div.p: A: All state/national competitions have either been cancelled or postponed. We will communicate any new dates.

p.strong: Q: My child is not on free/reduced meals, can I still get meals?

div.p: A: Absolutely! iLearn, on behalf of your Charter, has applied for a program that affords ALL students with a breakfast/lunch during the iContinue Program of instruction.

p.strong: Q: What if I can’t make it, can a relative pick up my children’s meals?

div.p: A: Of course we prefer to see our parents but understand the difficulties the school closures put on your family. Just have them identify the student(s) to the staff.

p.strong: Q: If the school is closed should we be going in to pick up meals?

div.p: A: All meal pickups will be outside at the designated location. You just have to drive up and the meal will be delivered at your car window.

p.strong: Q: Can I pick up meals for multiple days?

div.p: A: Not at this time. To ensure freshness of meals, we do not have plans to distribute multiple days of meals.

div.h3: School Closure Letters for Working Parents

div.class: elementor-element elementor-element-94f3ca0 elementor-icon-list--layout-inline elementor-align-center elementor-widget elementor-widget-icon-list

div.p: iLearn Schools is proud to use digital learning platforms to provide high-quality STEAM-based education. Due to our preparation over time, we believe we are prepared for an extended period of virtual learning (iContinue Learning). iLearn Schools has a strong instructional technology program in place already, and is well-prepared to provide distance learning services for students. In case of a school closing, here is some information about iLearn Schools’ academic continuity plan:

Continuity of learning is the continuation of education in the event of a prolonged school closure during an emergency. In case of circumstances that interrupt normal school attendance, Virtual Presence is extending “teaching” through technology. All teachers of all subject matters including electives courses will deliver the course content, share digital resources, post announcements, communicate with students, administer tests, and grade assignments – all online. iLearn Schools has developed this Academic Continuity Plan to proactively preserve the functions of academic programs, making them as close to ideal as traditional instruction.

Communication: iLearn Schools will communicate effectively and in a timely manner with all parents, students, and staff. Weekly broadcasts will be shared with all parents, students, and staff to keep the entire iLearn Schools community up-to-date on the latest information. The main communication tools already in place are:
Email and Class Dojo. Schools will continue using their existing email service as the main communication tool for grades 4-12 and ClassDojo for K-3.

Telephone Broadcasting System. School leaders can use the existing phone broadcasting system. Administrators can use telephone calling to support the distribution of notifications and to provide information to students, faculty, and staff during a prolonged closure.

Social Media. All our schools have Twitter and Facebook accounts. Social media can be used for general announcements particularly because they are easy to access on different devices, including: cell phones, tablets, and computers.
Online Tools: Online tools can be grouped into two main categories:
Learning Platforms and Delivery Modes
Content Creation/Feeding

Learning Management Systems. An LMS allows teachers to share and store instructional materials, such as: assignments, worksheets, and assessments; track student progress and grade work; communicate with students; conduct online class meetings; and much more. We have been using Schoology as a learning management system for grades 4-12 and Google Classroom for grades 2-3.

Other than Schoology and Google Classroom, the following technologies are available as potential distance delivery modes to maintain academic continuity. Each individual teacher will prepare his/her “Academic Continuity Plan” for his/her classes that include a variety of online tools. Preparing a teacher’s virtual classroom tools and preparing materials in advance will allow teachers to smoothly transition from face-to-face learning to online education.

td.p: Live lecturing, one way (students can interact via text only)
Sharing any digital file online (Any PDF, Word, image, multimedia, link, etc.)

div.p: Designing for Different Grade Levels. Instructional design, course design, and plans for support will be aligned with the skill level of each grade level. Below are descriptions of technologies, and resources currently available for online education:

td.p: Online gradebook, send announcements, post documents, create assignments with rubrics, and use discussion boards. Teachers can disseminate assignments and assessments to students, as well as facilitate discussions among students.
Connects primary school teachers, students, and families through communication to share announcements and homework.
Video Conference tool, similar to GoToMeeting
Allows live web conferencing and screen sharing with students.
Video Conference tool, similar to GoToMeeting
Upload your own videos, record webcam lectures, and share them through Youtube
Creating, administering, and tracking online assessments.

div.h2: The tools below will be used for content creation:

td.p: IXL allows teachers and parents to monitor the progress of their students and motivate them through interactive games and practice questions.
Splash Math is an educational program that provides comprehensive coverage of the curriculum with over 300 skills for Grades K-3
Mystery Science provides interactive science lessons that students can complete at home.
Khan Academy provides short lessons in the form of videos. Its website also includes supplementary practice exercises and materials for educators.
Used for weekly spelling and vocabulary words
Ask a question and poll students. Can be used in a live presentation.
Allows teachers to post explanatory videos, assign activities, track student completion, and assess using a grading scale.
Allows teachers to create interactive lessons that can contain virtual field trips, quizzes, collaborate boards, polls, matching activities, and more. https://nearpod.com/coronavirus
Teachers create lessons or use one from their library to make interactive lessons for students that provide instant feedback. Students can work at their own pace.
Provides a resource for reading comprehension that gives feedback to teachers.
Provides videos on multiple subjects, as well as short quizzes.

Pearson enVision for middle school Math allows teachers to assign learning materials as well as assignments to students while monitoring progress. The platform offers teachers the flexibility to assign different materials (MathXL) to different learners (i.e. to differentiate) and it also has an adaptive component (Adaptive Practice powered by Knewton – per lesson) that changes the level of difficulty. Teachers can select current topics and/or allow students to review/practice older ones discussed earlier in the year.
https://www.mathgames.com/ allows students to practice various skills. The student can select a grade level or a skill and play a game that helps him/her to practice a taught concept.

Articles for Math, S.S., ELA, and Science. Allows teachers to see students’ progress and gives teachers the option to create their own questions (e.g. open ended, MC. fill in the blanks and polls). Use the free version! https://www.activelylearn.com/
Teachers can assign multiple reading assignments with different due dates.
Allows teachers to assign reading with pre-attached questions and quizzes
ABCmouse- phonics activities and games for K-2
Reading IQ- online books and reading assessments for K-6

div.p: Document continually updated​

iLearn Schools Instructional Technology iNewsletter is a common platform for sharing technology news, tips, best practices, and happenings at iLearn Schools. Please find the archive of iNewsletters at the link attached.
School websites, as always, serve as the main information center for all kinds of student data.
Bergencharter.org for Bergen Arts and Science Charter School
Passaiccharter.org for Passaic Arts and Science Charter School
Patersoncharter.org for Paterson Arts and Science Charter School
Hudsoncharter.org for Hudson Arts and Science Charter School
Bronxcharter.org for Bronx Arts and Science Charter School

Special Education teachers will be assigned as co-teachers in the general education teacher’s Schoology account, and will have access to all of their Special Education students’ academic assignments, grades, and records. This will allow Special Education students to still receive close support from our Special Education teachers throughout distance learning. All Special Education teachers will be responsible for co-planning with the General Education teacher. Compensatory services will be provided upon returning to school. Case managers will also be available during contracted work hours.

p.br: Support materials will be provided for all ELL students through NetGeo (myngconnect.com). For those students following push-in support schedules, a joint account will be shared between ELL teachers and General Education teachers. For pull-out support, usernames and passwords will be provided for students by their ELL teacher. ClassDoJo will be utilized in grades K-2, and all communications will take place through this platform.

div.p: Document continually updated

ALL Students are eligible and will be provided breakfast and lunch in the case of school closures. Please complete the COVID-19 Parent Questionnaire (https://forms.gle/o2K13zRXUBoGGbCCA), so that we can prepare an adequate amount of food for all participating families. Please note that our pickup locations will be:

p.br:
Bergen ASCS Middle School Campus
200 MacArthur Avenue
Garfield, N.J. 07026

Passaic ASCS Middle School Campus
188 1st Street
Passaic, N.J. 07055

Passaic ASCS Clifton 4 School Campus
43 Clifton Ave.
Clifton, N.J. 07011

Paterson ASCS Middle-High School Campus
225 Grand Street
Paterson, N.J. 07501

Hudson ASCS Middle School Campus
114 Chestnut Street
Kearny, N.J. 07032 AND

p.span: Hudson ASCS School Jersey City Campus
p.br:
2737 John F. Kennedy Blvd,
Jersey City, NJ 07306

div.p:
Bronx ASCS District:
Bronx ASCS Elementary School Campus
925 Hutchinson River Pkwy.
Bronx, N.Y. 10465
Please note that meals will be cold and packaged in a grab-and-go style for ease of delivery and pick up by students or parents/guardians.
Food pickup time: 7:00 a.m. – 12:30 p.m. at each location
All pickups will be grab and go!

iLearn Schools’ distance learning program requires students to have high speed wifi connectivity and computers at home. iLearn Schools is exploring alternative solutions to help families with no wifi connectivity and computers to use at home. Please complete the survey (https://forms.gle/o2K13zRXUBoGGbCCA) if you would like to benefit from this service.

div.h2: Important Notes for Staff and Faculty

ul.li: In case of a school closure, all staff members will work remotely except custodial staff and Central Office personnel.
All staff must be available from home during the work hours of 7:30 a.m. to 3:45 p.m.
School Administrators must hold a minimum of one online meeting per week.
Academic Program Directors and School Administrators will provide instructional staff with more detailed guidance and resources around distance learning through campus-based Professional Development.
Custodial staff will follow the facilities department’s guidance and directions.
Central Office will remain open at all times.

Support materials will be provided for all ELL students through NetGeo (myngconnect.com). For those students following push-in support schedules, a joint account will be shared between ELL teachers and General Education teachers. For pull-out support, usernames and passwords will be provided for students by their ELL teacher. ClassDoJo will be utilized in grades K-2, and all communications will take place through this platform.

In order to ensure educational continuity in the event of a school closure, school admin team and non-instructional staff will get together to prepare work, materials, and resources that will be needed to be productive at home.

p.a: COVID-19 Coronavirus Customer FAQ with Pharmacy
Cigna Virtual Care Client Flyer with Behavioral Health
